awd_titl_txt: Intruder dynamics in fluid saturated granular medium
awd_abstract_narration:
Media composed of solid grains and fluids occur in geology, oil recovery, and chemical and food processing industries.  The motion of an intruder in these situations, for example, the burrowing or locomotion of an octopus through the sea bed, is currently difficult to predict.  This is true whether the intruder is a large, rigid object that is denser than the solid grains or an active object such as a robot or worm.  This research will develop a set of models that predict the detailed motion of intruders as a function of their physical properties and those of the medium. In addition, experiments will be performed with three-dimensional imaging techniques that allow simultaneous measurement of the intruder motion and the motion of the surrounding grains and fluid. The experiments and models will focus first on spherical intruders, and then extend to rods and multi-link robot intruders.  Design rules for these robots, which might be used to probe marine sediments, will be developed by studying the motion of freshwater worms. Ultimately, the results will be applied to efficient processing of wet granular materials in industry and the development of robots that can move through complex environments.  The project will provide research experience for students at various stages of their educational careers in a collaborative environment focused on STEM.

Intruder motion in dry granular materials has been studied to understand non-ergodic behavior in dynamical systems and segregation mechanisms.  However, an understanding of intruder dynamics in fluid saturated granular medium, important to an even wider range of natural and industrial systems, is largely underdeveloped. Rheological descriptions of the medium developed recently as a function of dimensionless inertial and viscous numbers from granular and suspensions research will be combined with low-Reynolds number hydrodynamic resistive force theory to describe the motion of the intruder in multi-phase particulate systems. Closely coupled fluorescence-tagged internal imaging techniques will be further developed and used to measure the rearrangements of the granular and fluid phase at the single-grain level. Detailed measurement of the shape and orientation dependent drag of the intruder combined with the connection of the observed drag to the micromechanics of the medium will enable the development of a fundamental rheology model of active and passive intruder dynamics through wet granular medium. The project activities will also support a range of educational activities including enabling undergraduate and graduate laboratory research experience, and outreach activities targeting school students and members of the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to understand the dynamics of an intruder, in the form of a solid body or an active worm, moving inside a porous granular medium which can rearrange when driven over a critical load. The question we sought to understand was what would be the drag force encountered by objects of various shapes such as spheres and rods, as they moved through the medium, as a function of the size of the object in relation to the size of the granular particles of the medium. To accomplish this, a series of laboratory apparatus were designed to perform measurements with pressure sensors and imaging systems. The data obtained had to be processed and then analyzed by developing granular physics theories that could explain not only the drag, but also the forces required to move the object with a prescribed rate. In particular, a model developed in the context of viscous fluids was tested and developed towards application in fluid-saturated medium, as in sediments at the bottom of river or ocean beds, and the blending of materials in industry. A summary of the intellectual merit impacts of our work is as follows: We developed a fully tested formula for the drag experienced by a spherical and cylindrical shaped solid object as a function of its size and speed, and the material properties of the medium including the mass, size and friction of the granular medium, and the density and viscosity of the interstitial fluid. Our work found that wake effects behind a moving body needs to be considered in order to calculate the drag experienced by multiple bodies moving relative to the medium, i.e. the principle of superposition did not hold. By performing experiments with commonly found limbless worms, we developed an understanding of the strategies used to move through a granular bed as a function of depth inside the granular bed. The study also revealed the power of using dual strokes, combining transverse as well as longitudinal motion, to navigate through medium; and examined the changing character of the medium with pressure. The results were written, peer reviewed, and published in leading international scientific journals. The results were also presented at local, national, and international conferences to inform practitioners of granular physics and multiphase flow. A summary of the broader impacts of our work is as follows: The deeper understanding reached by our study of solid bodies moving inside granular medium will lead to a more efficient design of mixers, reactors, and blenders of a range of consumer goods that have fluid and granular components. The activities involved in performing the research, including designing and building the apparatus, obtaining and analyzing data, and writing and presenting reports to the scientific and broader community were important to training the next generation of investigators in a wide range of STEM fields. Undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers received education in the methods used to effectively study granular matter and hydrodynamics. The results of the scientific study were posted on archives so that anyone with an internet connection, across the world, can download the outcomes of the study freely.     

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2023
Modified by: Arshad A Kudrolli
